article.title: Community Targeted Spam: A Middle Ground Between General Spam and Spear Phishing

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE about the future of phishing as depicted in Figure 1?
choices: Spear phishing will become less effective.
CTP is predicted to be more effective than massive phishing but require more effort.
CTP will require as much effort as spear phishing.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the "Discard co-authors" step in the workflow shown in Figure 2?
choices: To avoid raising suspicion by targeting close collaborators of the impersonated scholar.
To limit the number of emails sent and avoid being flagged as spam.
To ensure that the targeted researchers are not working on the same topic as the impersonated scholar.
To personalize the email further by mentioning specific co-authored publications.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the workflow shown in Figure 3, what information is NOT directly extracted from the impersonated scholar\'s Google Scholar page?
In the "Advanced NLG" section, how do the authors suggest Advanced NLG could be used to craft more convincing phishing emails?
choices: By generating random but plausible sounding research topics.
By automatically scraping and replicating the writing style of real academics.
By analyzing public data to identify and exploit individual researchers\' vulnerabilities and aspirations.
By automatically translating existing phishing emails into multiple languages.
